facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 11th January, 1954, of the High Court of Judicature of Mysore in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953, quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 11th January, 1954, of the High Court of Judicature of Mysore in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953, quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53.

facts.text: The appellant and respondent No. 1, as well as eight other persons, were duly nominated candidates for election to the Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency at the general election held in January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondent No. 1, as well as eight other persons, who figured as respondents Nos. 2 to 9 in the proceeding before the High Court, were duly nominated candidates for election to the Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency at the general election of that State held in January , 1952.

facts.text: Polling took place on the 4th January, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on the 4th January, 1952, and the votes were counted on the 26th of January following.

facts.text: Votes were counted on the 26th of January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the votes were counted on the 26th of January following. As a result, of the counting the respondent No. 1 was found to have secured 8,093 votes which was the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 secured 8,093 votes, appellant obtained 8,059 votes.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, of the counting the respondent No. 1 was found to have secured 8,093 votes which was the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes.

facts.text: Returning Officer declared respondent No. 1 successful candidate, published in Mysore Gazette on 11th February 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer declared the respondent No. 1 to be the successful candidate and this declaration was published in the Mysore Gazette on the 11th February, 1952.

facts.text: Notice of return of election expenses of respondent No. 1 published on 31st March 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1. lodged his return of election expenses with the necessary declaration sometime after that and notice of this return was published on the 31st March, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition dated 10th April 1952, sent by registered post to Election Commission, received on 14th April 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed a petition before the Election Commission, challenging the validity of the election, inter alia, on the grounds that there was violation of the election rules in regard, to certain matters and that the respondent No. I by himself or through his agents were guilty of a number of major corrupt practices which materially affected the result of the election. This petition, which bears date, 10th of April, 1952, was sent by registered post to the Election Commission and was -actually received by the latter on the 14th of April, following.

facts.text: Election Commission referred matter to Election Tribunal at Shimoga.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Commission referred the matter for determination by the Election Tribunal at Shimoga and it came up for hearing before it on the 25th of October, 1952.

facts.text: On 25th October 1952, appellant filed application for amendment of petition under Order VI rule 17 CPC, adding alternative prayer to declare entire election void.

anchor.surface_text: On that date the appellant filed an application for amendment of the -petition, heading it as one under Order VI, rule 17, of the Civil Procedure Code, and the only amendment sought for was a modification of the prayer clause by adding a prayer for declaring the entire election to be void.

facts.text: Election Tribunal granted amendment despite objection by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Despite the objection of respondent No. 1, the Tribunal granted this prayer for amendment.

facts.text: Tribunal by majority 2:1 found issues 1,5,6,11,12,14 in favour of petitioner: infringement of poll commencement time, procuring motor bus of Ahmed Jan, assistance of govt servants, false return of expenses, election procured by corrupt practices, petitioner would have majority but for practices.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by a majority of 2 to 1 found all these issues in favour of the petitioner and against the respondent No. 1 and on the strength of their findings on these issues, declared the election of respondent No. 1 to be void and the petitioner to have been duly elected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal judgment dated 15th January 1953, declared election of respondent No.1 void and petitioner duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Tribunal is dated the 15th of January, 1953.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 filed application under article 226 before Mysore High Court on 5th February 1953 for certiorari to quash tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th February, 1953, the respondent No. I presented an application before the Mysore High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ or direction in the nature of certiorari calling for the records of the proceeding of the Election Tribunal in Election Petition No. I of 195253 and quashing the same including the order pro- nounced by the Tribunal as mentioned above.

facts.text: Mysore High Court by Division Bench allowed petition on 11th January 1954, issued writ of certiorari quashing tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 11th January, 1954, of the High Court of Judicature of Mysore in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953, quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53. S. Krishnaswami Iyengar  K. S. Venkataranga Iyengar and M. S. K. Iyengar, with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under articles 132(1) and 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the appellant has come up to this Court on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under articles 132 1  and 133 1   c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Polling at Booth No. I for Ajjampur fixed at 8 A.M. did not commence until about half an hour later.

anchor.surface_text: Has there been infringement of the rules relating to the time of commencement of poll by reason of the fact that the polling at Booth No. I for Ajjampur fixed at Ajjampur to take place at 8 A.m. did not really commence until about half an hour later as alleged in paragraph 4 of the petition

facts.text: First respondent procured service bus of Ahmed Jan running between Tarikere and Hiriyur for conveying voters.

anchor.surface_text: Did the 1st respondent hire and procure a motor bus which was a service bus running between Tarikere and Hiriyur, belonging to one Ahmed Jan, as alleged in paragraph I of the particulars and thereby commit the corrupt practice referred to in it ?

facts.text: Bus of Ahmed Jan carried about 60 voters in two trips to polling booths.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that the bus of Ahmed Jan, which was procured by respondent No. 1, did carry to the polling booths about 60 voters in two trips and in the, circumstances of the case it could be legitimately presumed that the majority of them did vote for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: First respondent took assistance of government servants including Patel Paramesshwarappa to further election prospects.

anchor.surface_text: Did the 1st respondent take the assistance of a number of Government servants to further the prospects of his election as alleged in paragraph 2 of the list of particulars ?

facts.text: Return of election expenses by first respondent false in material particulars, omitted expenses exceeding Rs. 5000 limit.

anchor.surface_text: Is the return of election expenses lodged by the 1st respondent false in material particulars and has the 1st respondent omitted to include in the return of election expenses, expenses incurred by him in connection with the election which would easily exceed the sanctioned limit of, Rs. 5,000 as per particulars stated in paragraph 7 of the list of particulars

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, vacated writ issued by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported and this appeal must be allowed. The writ issued by the High Court will therefore be vacated.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC allows appeal, vacates HC writ, restores tribunal order

holdings.text: High Court under Article 226 can issue certiorari only where tribunal acts without jurisdiction, in excess of jurisdiction, in violation of natural justice, refuses jurisdiction, or error apparent on face of record causing manifest injustice; not as appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: Such writs as are referred to in article 226 are obviously intended to enable the High Court to issue them in grave cases where the subordinate Tribunals or bodies or officers act wholly without jurisdiction, or in excess of it, or in violation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows English and Indian precedents on scope of certiorari; supervisory not appellate; quotes Halsbury, Atkin LJ, Morris LJ, prior SC cases.

holdings.text: No lack of jurisdiction: election petition presented within time as deemed presented on 14 April under s.81(2)(b) ROPA, within 14 days excluding publication date 31 March under r.119.

anchor.surface_text: We may take it therefore that 14th of April was the date when the election petition could be deemed to have been presented to the Election Commission under section 81 2  b  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies textual interpretation excluding date of publication per canons of construction; respondent concedes.

holdings.text: No lack of jurisdiction re amendment: amendment only added alternative prayer, original prayer granted, immaterial; no general amendment power needed.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the mere fact that the Tribunal granted the petitioners application for amendment becomes altogether immaterial and has absolutely no bearing on the actual decision in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No change to averments; s.83(3) irrelevant as not general amendment; outcome same without amendment.

holdings.text: No excess jurisdiction re bus procuring: allegation of procuring by self or agent covers Ahmed Jan acting with knowledge/connivance; finding on evidence within pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this view of the High Court can be supported. In paragraph 8 of the petition the appellant definitely stated that the first respondent by himself and through his agent committed major corrupt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings in paras 8-9 allege self/agent/knowledge/connivance; Tribunal finding of fact based on evidence.

holdings.text: No excess jurisdiction re declaring petitioner elected: Tribunal found 60 voters via bus likely for respondent wiping 34-vote margin; specific finding on issue 14 supported.

anchor.surface_text: If the votes of at least 40 or 50 of these persons be left out of account as being procured by corrupt practice of the first respondent, the latters majority by 34 votes would be completely wiped

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of 60 voters presumed majority for respondent; deducts enough to reverse result; not speculation.

holdings.text: No error apparent on face re poll commencement delay: Tribunal assessed material effect under s.100(2)(c) on circumstances/probabilities; not sole basis for declaring petitioner elected.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot say that this is an error apparent on the face of the record which would entitle the High Court to interfere by writ of certiorari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not patent error; proper under Act considering probabilities; combined with other findings.
